thread.title: People have been sharing this Wordsworth poem about Westminster Bridge
thread.title_full: People have been sharing this Wordsworth poem about Westminster Bridge

author: Jen
title: People have been sharing this Wordsworth poem about Westminster Bridge
text:
(Picture: Universal News And Sport / Twitter) Earth has not anything to show more fair 
Dull would he be of soul who could pass by 
A sight so touching in its majesty. 
After yesterday’s terror attack on Westminster Bridge, people have been sharing this poem by William Wordsworth.
Four people died when a terrorist drove a rented car down the pavement of the bridge, mowing down pedestrians, then crashed into railings outside Parliament and stabbed a policeman.
Amid the scenes of horror, the poem had extra resonance today.
‘Ne’er saw I, never felt a calm so deep,’ Andy Richardson tweeted, saying that he was ‘proud of the quiet dignity and resolve in London.’
Tim Sapwell tweeted: ‘We must never stop seeing this through William Wordsworth’s eyes.’
We must never stop seeing this through William Wordsworth's eyes: "Earth has not anything to show more fair". pic.twitter.com/2fJ34wi24h 
— Tim Sapwell (@TimSapwell) March 23, 2017 
Ne’er saw I, never felt, a calm so deep!
(Wordsworth: Composed upon Westminster Bridge)
Proud of the quiet dignity and resolve in London
— Andy Richardson (@iamthepeanut) March 23, 2017 
'Composed upon Westminster Bridge, September 3 1802' – William Wordsworth.
London's heart remains mighty ❤ #Westminister pic.twitter.com/cXRLQIJSdT 
— Anna Maria Barry (@AnnaMariaB87) March 22, 2017 
Sir Ian McKellen reading Wordsworth’s ‘Composed Upon Westminster Bridge’ https://t.co/BQxQa79814 
— Kirk McElhearn (@mcelhearn) March 23, 2017 
"Dear God! The very houses seem asleep
And all that mighty heart is lying still!"
Composed Upon Westminster Bridge – William Wordsworth 1802 pic.twitter.com/hshfz2SUBP 
— George (GB) Revel (@RevelLaw) March 22, 2017 

Composed Upon Westminster Bridge, September 3, 1802 
William Wordsworth, 1770 – 1850 
Earth has not anything to show more fair:
Dull would he be of soul who could pass by
A sight so touching in its majesty:
This City now doth, like a garment, wear
The beauty of the morning; silent, bare,
Ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples lie
Open unto the fields, and to the sky;
All bright and glittering in the smokeless air.
Never did sun more beautifully steep
In his first splendour, valley, rock, or hill;
Ne’er saw I, never felt, a calm so deep!
The river glideth at his own sweet will:
Dear God! the very houses seem asleep;
And all that mighty heart is lying still! 
Click here to read more of our coverage of the London terror attack
